question: By shape, what type of galaxy is the Milky Way?

content.source_1: In the Hubble morphological classification, spiral galaxies are one of the main types of galaxies.
content.source_2: Observations (radio, infrared, and stellar kinematics) show the Milky Way has a rotating disk with spiral arms and a central bar; it is classified as a barred spiral galaxy.
content.source_3: A barred spiral galaxy is a subclass of spiral galaxies.
content.source_4: If an object is a spiral galaxy, then in answering “what type of galaxy is it?” it can be described as “a spiral galaxy.”
content.source_5: From our vantage point inside the Milky Way, interstellar dust in the disk heavily obscures optical views, making the Galaxy’s large-scale spiral pattern difficult to discern directly in visible light.
content.source_6: In galaxy morphology, disk galaxies that have a prominent bulge and disk but show little or no visible spiral structure in optical images are classified as lenticular (S0) galaxies.
